intro: Sclerolaena gardneri, commonly known as the Gardner's screwbrush, is a flowering plant native to southern Africa. It belongs to the Proteaceae family and is characterized by its woody, branched stems and dense, evergreen foliage. The plant produces small, clustered yellow flowers that bloom in spring, attracting pollinators such as bees and birds. It is typically found in rocky or sandy soils and thrives in full sun conditions. Due to its ornamental value and ecological importance, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens and conservation areas.
